Alex reaches over, brushes back Katharine's hair. He kiss gently. Gets up.

Mirrored on three sides. Alex, a towel wrapped around his waist, holds a toothpaste tube. Sticks his tongue out, ex himself in the mirror. Katharine stands by the door in a robe. Arms folded, she' grinning. Enjoys watching him, catching him in that silly act with his tongue. Through the mirror, Alex sees her, smiles back. He also n the side of his neck -- the macaw bite, now a purplish ma against his skin. He touches it, runs his finger along it A quick glance at Katharine, he turns, bolts from the bat
Alex dresses in a rush. Katharine's at a loss.
Hey!
At the bar in the Plaza. (hopping about as he puts on a sock) -- Doyle hated the damn bird. He holds the bow tie in his hand, not knowing what to do it. Stuffs it in his pocket, then takes it out.
(hands the bow tie to Katharine) Take care of this, I'll be back, okay? He hurries out.
(yelling after him) Rada...?!
Alex, still in tuxedo shirt and pants, dashes up the step
Checking a directory on the wall. Alex finds what he's looking for, moves off.
We see Alex turn a corner, stride TOWARD CAMERA. He stops in front of an open office door which reads: 'DR. W. MINT

Alex peers into a small office, sees a SHORT BALDING MAN in his late thirties. Long strands of hair from the side are plastered down on top of his head. The office is clut Alex recognizes a kindred spirit.
Mintz is erasing something from a piece of paper. Alex walks in, smiles, feels sort of at home. Mintz looks up.
Dr. Mintz?
(pointing to himself) Yes. Mintz, comma, William.
Alex Rada.
Hello, Alex Rada.
I'd like to talk to you about an autopsy you performed. Mintz leans back in his chair, waves his arm at a set of cabinets.
Which one?
I don't have a case number. It was recent. A woman. Susan Blake.

(thinking; nods) That one I remember. Beautiful woman. MINTZ (cont'd.) Bizarre. You do so many, you usually forget. You insurance? Mintz raises his eyebrows, ala Groucho Marx, points to Alex's clothes.
Formal investigation?
Sure, why not?
You guys are doing well these days. (shrugs) Public record.
I need your help. The forms'll take me forever. Mintz gets up. Gestures for Alex to follow.
Okay, Rada comma Alex, c'mon.
A PATHOLOGIST washing up at a sink. A covered body on a t Mintz looks around, spots a circular drill. Turns it on. eyes bulge -- bewildered horror.
(nervously) Hey, what, uh...you're not going to...
(waves him off) No, no, no, relax. Let's go.
Alex points to the wound on his neck.
I think the girl had the same mark.
I'll check the report. Take a look at the pictures.

The autopsy report and photos are spread out on the desk. Alex and Mintz are going over them. Mintz bends down, pulls some files off the top of a tiny refrigerator, looks around for a place to put them. Hands to Alex, who places them on a chair. Bending down again, Mintz opens the refrigerator, finds h a salami. Grabs it and some bread. The WHIRRING of the CIRCULAR DRILL, it slices through the salami. Mintz cuts a few pieces, makes a sandwich.
Want some?
I'll pass. (pointing to photo) See, here -- It's the same kind of bite I have on my neck Mintz eats his sandwich, looks over the autopsy report.
Okay...
It's a bird bite, right? A macaw.
A bird with a hooked bill wouldn't be inconsistent with the findings -- Maybe a parrot.
And how long before she died did she get the bite?
Hard to say, Alex Rada. Within, oh, twenty-four hours of death. Alex paces the small room, thinking.
(holding out sandwich) Sure you don't want a bite?
(waves him off) Look -- could she have been brought to the apartment unconscious, then killed?
She was definitely killed in the apartment --
-- With a sharpened screwdriver, maybe?

Or an ice pick. See?...Then that extraordinary wound extending to the symphysis pubis. (showing Alex a photo; he tries hard not to look) The contusions didn't cause death. They were administered before, so it wouldn't be inconsistent with the findings.
Is that a yes? She could have been knocked unconscious somewhere else and then killed in the apartment? -- Would that be consistent with the findings?
If you put it that way -- yes.
(brightening) Thanks, Doc. (about the sandwich) You know, you should try that with some nice Ukrainian bread.
We see Alex exit the florist holding what appears to be a a single flower wrapped in tissue paper. He no longer wears the tuxedo shirt and pants; he is dressed (for Alex anyway) normally.
Alex steps off the elevator, moves to Katharine's door. He holds a flower, a single white rose -- the romantic sa He RINGS the BELL.
...Who is it?

It's me, Alex. There is a long moment, perhaps muffled sounds from insid Finally, Katharine opens the door. She peers around the d doesn't look that happy to see him. She notices the flowe opens the door all the way to let him in. Guilt written a over her -- a kind of tenderness, too.
Come on in, Alex.
For you. Hands her the flower, waits for a response. She can't mak eye contact.
It's beautiful. He moves to kiss her, she turns her head so the kiss is o cheek. Katharine strides off with the flower.
What's the matter? Lays the rose on a glass coffee table, turns to Alex.
...About last night... He can tell what's coming -- his defense is sarcasm.
Don't bother, I understand. I just work for you.

(sharp) -- That's not it -- and that's not fair. (beat, softer) Look, Alex...you wouldn't want me... I'm all confused, mixed up...You know we'd kill each other. All that constant bickering... The bedroom door opens, Frank Willis appears.
Hiya, Alex. Frank looks to Katharine, he feels rotten about this.
(annoyed, embarrassed) Frank!
Might as well get it over with, Katie. (to Alex) Sorry, Alex.

(staring at Katharine) ...You've been a busy little beaver. She lets the remark slide. Alex stands awkwardly, conscious of his hands, not knowin what to do with them. Slides them into the pockets of his coat.
Frank, maybe Alex and I should talk alone?
Sure...Sure, Katie.

(overlapping) No, no, don't let me interrupt. I'm just leaving. Alex, trying to hide his feelings, moves to the door with kind of swagger. Katharine grabs him. She glances back at Frank, who disappears inside.
...Alex, I like you very much. Very much...It's just that Frank and I...It's comfortable, Alex. He puts up with a lot. I just wasn't really sure...until all this. (a pause) Last night was my...
-- Fault? Is that what you're going to say, fault?

(stiffening now) No -- I'll tell you what it is, Rada. It's that I'm a sucker for decent guys. Men who never quite push hard enough, men who think they're tough, then let them- selves get ripped apart inside because they really care about something...only they won't admit it, even to themselves. (beat) Decent guys, Rada...like you. A long moment from Alex. He's unforgiving.
You left out decent young girls. Katharine's eyes narrow -- the hurt is there, but she won strike back.
Okay, Alex... (beat) ...Okay.
And try this one on, lady. Your... EfriendR...Susan Blake?...Alfred Lynch did her, not the Doyle kid.
(not certain she's grasped what Alex has just said) What? That's just crazy talk.
Is it? We'll see.
Alex, don't do anything stupid.
You paid me to do a job. Like you said, all I have to do is push a little harder, right?

Cars and buses. The glow from headlights. HONKING of HORN Alex crosses the street toward Central Park. From behind, Frank Willis catches up. They stand in the middle of the avenue as traffic whizzes by.
Look, Alex, it's just the way it is.
Right, Frank. Cars dodging them. Swerving. Honking.
Can we at least talk about this on the sidewalk?
I don't give a shit -- you love her?
About the only thing I care about, old buck. Alex nods, accepts this. He walks across the street. Fran waits for a car to pass, catches up again on the sidewalk opposite.
...I want you to know something, Alex. About Katie. I knew...about her affairs -- about the Blake girl. She wanted someone to find her. I helped.
Thanks for the business, Frank.
You think I'm an A-number-one putz, right? Alex stops, pats Frank on the shoulder.
It's been a long night all around. I'm going to go home. Why don't you go where you have to, Frank. Alex again moves up the block, Frank begins to follow, Alex waves him off.
Alex...
(turning toward Frank) ...Really, Frank. Alex turns away. We watch him pad downtown.

Quiet. Empty. A wall separates the entrance of the park from the sidewalk. Benches line Fifth Avenue in front of the wall. Alex, disconsolate, is not sitting on a bench, but on top the concrete wall. He stares off at the apartment buildin across the street. WE HOLD ON ALEX.

A squad car SCREECHES INTO FRAME. Another and then anothe POLICE jump out, guns drawn. FLASHLIGHTS spray the darkne Sprawled out on the sidewalk in a drunken stupor is Victo He slowly attempts to get up as two cops approach. He sta toward the brick of the townhouse, tries to prop himself near a window.
Etta looks out on this scene, half hidden by the partiall door.
They help him up. As they do, he pushes them away, spread his arms in a gesture as if to say, "Hey, I'm fine." One hand holding a bottle, Victor thrashes about, knocks a window pane, breaking it.
The policemen spin Victor around, grab the bottle, handcu him from behind.
Another patrolman moves toward Etta.
(above the sound) Shut it off! Can you shut it off? Etta disappears. The patrolman waits.
Two policemen put Victor in the car, one tucks the back o his head down as he pushes him into the back seat.
The alarm has stopped. A cop talks to Etta.
...Later. This is the Lynchs'. Mrs. Delaney Lynch and Mr. Alfred Lynch. Nobody's here now, later.
Yes, Ma'am. You be sure to turn that alarm back on now?
Don't you worry about that.
They leave, SIRENS BLARING.

As the squad cars move out, Alex emerges from near an iro overlooking the river. He sneaks toward another ground fl window. With the sirens still blaring, he breaks the pane It can hardly be heard above the din. He reaches in, unlatches the window lock, boosts himself
Alex moves about, pulls a flashlight from a pocket. In th b.g. there is a faint light coming from the downstairs quarters.
leading to the upstairs bedrooms. Alex points the flashli toward them.
Alex inspects the bedroom, looking for some connection be Alfred Lynch and Susan Blake. Finds a gun in the night ta examines it, puts it back.

going through the oak desk, filing cabinets, papers on a table. Nothing. Alex sits in the leather chair behind the desk, glances t the open window, thinking. Spots a few newspapers on top desk, leafs through them casually. They are all out of to papers: Utica, Syracuse, Albany -- all have articles abou campaign. A front page picture of Delaney Lynch in the Buffalo Evening News, her staff behind her. Alex notices something -- the long flowing hair of a woman in the background of the photo. He opens a drawer of the desk, then another. Where'd he see it? Finds the magnifyi glass he'd spotted.

head_text.subj: NEWSPAPER PHOTO SEEN THROUGH MAGNIFYING GLASS

text: Susan Blake is clearly visible near Hal Rennert and Alfre Lynch.

Alex folds the paper, stuffs it in his jacket. Places the magnifying glass back in the drawer, it makes a sound as closes it. Alex is up now. We HEAR a NOISE coming from the hallway. Instinctively, Alex pulls his gun from the hip holster, u the safety. From outside in the hallway:

...Mr. Lynch?...Jimmy Doyle, is that you...? Alex lowers the gun down to his side, stands very still. A long moment, then footsteps moving away from the study. Satisfied Etta has gone off, Alex turns toward the window Listening carefully, he hears ANOTHER SOUND, this time fr within the study. Someone else is in this room. Alex shines the flashlight toward the sound. He sees a pair of SMALL BEADY EYES. Alex makes a move to the window bumps his knee on the desk, knocks his gun loose -- THE GUN GOES OFF -- A CHILLING INHUMAN SCREAM next to him. Frantically, Alex points the flashlight toward the floor, grabs his gun. Leaps toward the window.
Alex running down the block, around the corner.

Alex still running through the streets. Looks behind. No one following. He stops to catch his breath. WE CAN NOW SEE FEATHERS on his jacket, in his hair. He notices t Breathing heavily, he brushes them off. It dawns on him, slight smirk.
Bye, bye, birdie.

Delaney and Alfred, both in robes, are up and about. Dela reaches for a bowl, places it on a counter. Alfred sits a the table. They look tired. Etta appears in the entrance to the kitchen, surprised to see the Lynchs.
(moving toward counter) Mrs. Lynch...? I'll do that.
That's all right, Etta, I'll take care of it this morning.
Yes, Ma'am. Etta exits. Delaney crosses to the refrigerator, retrieve some butter and eggs along with a carton of orange juice.
Nothing was taken?
I don't think so.
Son of a bitch! Why would someone do that? They were looking for something, Alfred. Moves to Alfred, pours him some juice.
What could they find? Don't let this interfere with what we have to do. Delaney crosses back to the counter. Heats a frying pan.

It was much simpler back when...remember, making you breakfast in the house on Legion Street? (beat; thinking) ...They didn't have to kill Griffin. It was planned. I'm telling you, Alfred, this was planned. Staring off now, Delaney CRACKS THE EGGS against the side the bowl. Lost in thought. A beat.
...That detective Katharine's seeing. He thinks he has reason to be susp...
(interrupts) Perhaps I should have a talk with Mr. Rada. A meeting...to discuss his future. Beating the eggs in the bowl.
Yes. Yes. And I want Katharine with me in Albany tomorrow.
Delaney pours in the eggs, the pan sizzles.
Of course, it's really not our affair. It's possible she may not see him again.

head_text.subj: A SUNLIT SKY BRACKETED BY TWO CITY SKYSCRAPERS

text: A man sits on a bench. We MOVE IN CLOSER. It's Alex. He's feeding pigeons from a brown paper bag. He holds a newspa under his arm. SCHOOL CHILDREN parade past, all in the unifrom of some private academy. Alex lingers on the bench, then moves to the railing of the ice rink to watch the skaters. Katharine Raines strides into view, stands next to Alex. doesn't look at her.
Thanks, Alex.
Anytime.
I still feel as though...
-- that's not what you wanted to talk about, is it? She takes a thick envelope from her coat, hands it to Ale
No, I brought you something. Alex opens it -- a whole lot of money. He flips through t bills, places the envelope in his pocket.

(still watching skaters) ...You know, the other night at that dinner party, I had a conversation with Alfred Lynch in his study. I thought he was trying to warn me off you... but it was Susan Blake he was talking about. I was a little slow.
I just don't believe it. Let the police handle it.
(turning toward her) The police? Why the police all of a sudden?
Take the money, Alex. It's finished. (beat) Just some freak...some crazy freak; it wasn't Alfred Lynch.

...He wouldn't get his hands dirty. (staring at her) You forget what they did to her? It was the Doyle kid, but he did it for Alfred Lynch...for ELynchR. When Doyle used to pick her up downtown, he was driving her to see your friend Alfred. ALEX (cont'd.) (beat) And I've got news for you, Susan Blake wasn't really missing, she was upstate -- with him.

(uncertain) How do you know that? I read it in the papers. Alex hands her the paper he carries under his arm -- the copy of the EBuffalo Evening NewsR. Katharine stops, studies the picture, looks to Alex.
(still resisting) ...it doesn't prove he had her killed. Why?
Susan Blake had trouble letting go. Maybe she was going to tell the future Senator, or the papers. Maybe Alfred got nervous...maybe he enjoyed it.
...Let me count the maybe's. You'll need something more than a newspaper picture and speculation about...
-- Well, I'll let you know tonight, Alfred wants to see me.
(incredulous) What?
Right. Why would Alfred Lynch want to see me, get some advice on a leveraged buyout, maybe? I'll call you tonight...

-- I won't be around tonight, I'm going to Albany with Delaney -- the last Veress debate. I want out, Alex. KATHARINE (cont'd.) I want the investigation finished. (she turns to leave) Just finish it now, okay? Alex grabs her arm, takes out the envelope. He removes a few bills, hands Katharine back the envelope with the res of the money.
(a wry smile) For expenses. Probably won't be able to use the rest anyway. (serious now) What does that mean, 'you want out?' -- That mean you don't want to know...or that you already know?

An eerie glow. The only illumination, the light from the tiffany lamp on the desk. Alex and Alfred sit across the desk from one another, sta not saying a word. Alfred's hands rest under his chin, as if in prayer. Finally:
You can't seriously believe I had something to do with this woman's death? It's delusional, Mr. Rada.
I think you were screwing her and you had your boy Doyle kill her...that's what I think. Alfred doesn't react, his eyes betray nothing.

You saw her picture in a newspaper. Lot's of women follow the campaign around, that's hardly an indictment for murder...Do you know I'm astonished by you? You've got balls, all right. Do you actually think you can challenge me? In this town? (beat) I'll tell you this: Nothing is going ALFRED (cont'd.) to stand in the way of my wife's election. You may not comprehend this, Mr. Rada, but I hold your future in my hands. Alfred rises to his feet, moves to the now empty perch of Macaw, swings it slowly back and forth. He faces away fro
You wouldn't be threatening me would you, Mr. Lynch?
(disdainful tone) Not at all, Mr. Rada.
You know I saw her, after. (beat) Her guts were in a puddle on the floor. Alfred turns toward Alex, just stares at him for a long moment.
Yeah...?
Someone broke in here last night. Deliberately killed our macaw. It was a vicious, spiteful act.
Maybe the bird had enemies.
Are you trying to be clever, Mr. Rada?
(mimicking Alfred's disdainful tone) Not at all, Mr. Lynch. A curl from Alfred's lip, not actually a smile.
You EareR interesting in your own way. Do you know EPolitics Among NationsR? I have it here somewhere. Puts a hand in his pocket, moves to the bookshelf. Looks for the volume. Can't find it.

In any case, it's the same among human beings -- one nation...one person, they're essentially irrelevant. It's power that counts. Power, Mr. Rada, is an elegant principle of universal law, the less you use, the more you accumulate. (beat) And if you EdoR use it and lose, its evanescent nature becomes clear. Alex stares blankly -- is this guy joking? A deep sigh fr Alfred, know he's not quite communicating. Tries the dire tack.
-- What I mean, Mr. Rada, is that if you go up against me, you better be damn sure you can win.
Well, Mr. Lynch, I'm going to give what you said a great deal of consideration. Yes sir...consideration.
(he does laugh -- in disbelief) You are a ballsy son of a bitch. (beat) Know Cargill, Finch and Wells?
Yeah, I know it. Big time law firm. So? .bp

They're looking for an investigator, I'll arrange it for you. We'll call it a lesson in power -- it enhances mine and you get a chance to accumulate a little of your own. I'd rather have you on my side of the line, even though, quite frankly, Mr. Rada, (enunciating slowly) you are one very small piece of shit.
I appreciate the sentiment.
It's your life after all...think about it.

Alex walks along the sidewalk opposite the Lynch townhous Glances back over his shoulder, sees Alfred through the w He's framed by the glow of the tiffany lamp, working on p at his desk. We follow Alex to the corner. Very little activity on Yor Avenue. HEADLIGHTS of a black sedan switch on, the car ro toward Alex, gains speed as it pulls away from the sidewa For a moment, Alex freezes. The car shoots by him. Alex turns, again looks back toward the Lynchs' study. Th light has gone out.
Alex is on the phone with Detective Demarko.

...I might have something for you. You may not like...What? No, don't worry. (beat) ...Hey, DeMarko I need a little favor...C'mon, would I do that? Look, can you check on a drunk and disorderly for me, up at the eleventh? The name is D apostrophe A-M-A-T-O...Victor... It couldn't have been much. If you would... A KNOCK on the door.

(raised voice toward the door) Yeah, hold on! (into phone) ...Yeah, pals, Demarko. Vagrants are my life, right. Will you check? Thanks, you're a prince...wha... a few days, okay. Right. Hangs up. Rises.
Who is it? From behind the door.
It's me, Alex -- Victor. Moves to the kitchen table, picks up a glass decanter of drops with a small ribbon attached. Alex strides toward t door.
I was just talking about you. (as he opens the door) Got you something...
His eyes bulge, a screwdriver planted in his neck. Victor clutches at it, falls toward Alex.
stunned, catches him with one hand, still holds the decan the other.

Holding another sharpened screwdriver, plunges it toward Alex's face. Instinctively, Alex holds up the decanter -- it blocks the weapon. The decanter is shattered, the contents spilling over the floor.

Doyle lunges at him again, but he slips over the gum drop on the floor. Falls. Sprawled on his back. Alex tries to lay Victor down gently, kicks at Doyle at t same time. Alex catches him square in the face, Doyle wri in pain.
He reaches for his gun, pulls it out.
on the floor, lashes out with the screwdriver, stabs Alex the leg.
as he screams in pain, "Son of a bitch." Tries to aim the at Doyle.
scrambles up, runs out the door.
down on one knee now, holding his leg. Looks to Victor, t him over. Nothing he can do for him anymore. Alex is up, half running, half hobbling out the door, dow stairs.

Alex spots Doyle running up the block. Braces himself and points his weapon. People near him scatter. He squints, can't quite see. Too much of a crowd up ahead anyway. Takes off after Doyle, forgetting his leg. We can see the blood drenching through his pant leg.
past street peddlers pushing their wares, past outdoor fruit stands still open -- not getting much closer to Doy Alex sees him turn down a side street.
Much quieter, no one about. We HEAR GLASS SHATTERING in the distance. Alex stops, listening for it again. He moves past the Ukrainian church we've seen before, toward a row of tenement buildings.

head_text.subj: THE STEPS OF A TENEMENT BUILDING

text: Alex peers in toward the entrance -- the inner glass door has been shattered. Not all that unusual in this neighborhood.

Inside, Alex checks the hall. Gun drawn. He moves cautiou toward the stairs. Climbing up slowly, he feels his leg f the first time, reaches around to touch the back of his p Stares dumbly at his bloodied hand.
Alex hugs the wall, quickly moves out into the light. Poi his gun toward the landing above. No one there.
Alex on the last set of stairs, pushes through the door.

We PAN the roof area -- unused brick smoke stacks, a flat tar-papered surface with no barrier at the roof's edge; no connection to the next tenement building, or to the Ukrainian church on the other side. Alex listens for a sound, can't hear anything but vague traffic noises below -- maybe Doyle is not here. Alex turns to leave, opens the roof door. As he does, fro above the roof door --
slashes out, rips through Alex's jacket.
clenches the arm, rips Doyle down from above the door.
on his back, a gun pointed in his face. We HEAR a CLICK as the A-90 is cocked.
Alex holds Doyle by his hair, the gun is pointed not at Doyle's head, but pressed against his crouch.
(pulling hard on Doyle's hair) Tell me what I want to hear, you fuckin' little cum stain or -- You - Are - Dead.

You want to know if I killed the bitch, too? Yeah. You think I'm afraid of dying, man? Not like your friend. Pissed in his pants. (beat; taunting Alex) It was my idea to rip her open -- And the blood all over the walls, too... (almost an ecstasy) ...It was majestic. Alex pulls Doyle's hair tighter, holds him over the edge the roof -- we can see the church steps, the street far below.
(contemptuous, challenging Alex) I fucked her, Rada...after. Alex. Losing it. Shouting now.
Why did you bring her back to that apartment!?
I do what I want, I do what I'm told. Fu -- cking majestic.
By Lynch? Alfred Lynch told you!? Doyle spits at Alex, shakes his head loose from Alex's gr Spreads his arms out as if to fly. Pushes off the roof. As he falls backward toward the street below:
(laughing and yelling as he plummets) Yeah! Lynch! Fuck you! Alex leans over the edge, watching him fall. We can make out a figure walking down the church steps.

The figure is Father Stefanyk. He glances up as Doyle cra onto the church steps next to him, landing with arms out- stretched in the shape of a cross. Father Stefanyk looks to the body, toward the sky, toward the body again. He kn crosses himself.
Lots of activity. Demarko has a folder open. Alex is next to him
Forget it.
She was knocked unconscious and then brought back to that apartment -- EthenR she was killed.
You got something that isn't old news?
Why did Doyle go to all the trouble to bring her up there? He could have did her and dumped the body anywhere.
What the hell does this have to do with Alfred Lynch?

Susan Blake had a lover, a lover that paid for that place -- maybe Lynch didn't know who it was, but he was going to lay it on whoever was keeping her...and he was going to leave it to you to find out who. Then I came along and screwed things up for him.
In the first place, Susan Blake paid for that place every month, with her own checks.
Yeah, so where did she get the money?

...Maybe she earned it. Look, Rada, you don't really think I'm going to arrest Alfred Lynch -- EAlfred Lynch yetR, on some cockamamie theory about a lover and why the Doyle kid does the girl in her own apartment? The Doyle kid was a freak show -- he was into whaddaya call it, uh, performance artwork -- that's why he does her there with all the blood...like a ritual, see?
Doyle admitted it was Alfred Lynch. DeMarko shakes his head, grimaces. Speaks to Alex as thou were incapable of comprehension.

Do you know if I arrested Alfred Lynch on the basis of what you've been saying they'd have my shield. EAt bestR, DEMARKO (cont'd.) I'd be doing dispatch duty at the borough, answering phones -- giving out log numbers all day. I don't want to do that. Alex leans on the desk, grabs a pencil from several in a starts tapping the pencil on the desktop as he listens.
Now, this case is closed. The lieutenant says it's closed, the assistant chief says it's closed and I say it's closed, okay?
Okay, DeMarko, but let me guess? Nothing to the press until EafterR the election, right?
(defensive) That's the way it's coming down, yeah. There are some loose ends, some paper work, sure -- so?
Right. After the election.

Rada, what are you knocking your head against? It doesn't work. And where the hell is this so called lover -- you got absolutely nothing. Alex looks to Demarko, realizes he's right. Sticks the pe back in the mug, gets up, strides for the door.
(yelling after him) Hey, Rada, where you going? ...Albany.
A commercial flight lands, taxis towards a gate.
Alex moves though the airport with other passengers.
A cab pulls up. Alex get out, enters the hotel.
Delaney and her campaign aides. Last minute details on th Peter Veress debate. Clipboards. Pacing. Jokes.
...Sure, from his perspective he has nothing to lose.
I want to grind him, go over sixty percent on Tuesday.
We may be vulnerable on the crime issue, he'll do the prosecutor Veress number.

That sounds like a Frank Willis remark. (glances over to Frank, smiles) I think I can hit the curve ball, Hal. Just throw back the statistics at him. Nobody's going to be listening to Peter Veress anyway, they're all going to be watching for that little tic. Some laughter. Except for Katharine. She seems preoccupie
Every one of those little babies is worth at least a half a percentage point. Press guys have a pool on how many. More laughter.
(checks around) That everything? Okay, guys, I'd like to relax a little. Frank, Hal, David Garth and a FEW AIDES start packing up. Katharine lingers, moves to Delaney.
Katharine?
Maybe this isn't the best time?
What's up? Delaney strides toward the bedroom portion of the suite. Katharine follows. The men file out the door toward the hall.
Alfred met with Alex Rada yesterday.
Alfred's gotten him a position at Cargill, Finch.
What? You're joking? Alex Rada?
Delaney sits at a dressing table, turns toward Katharine.
I believe so. (beat) He's accepted. We thought that's what you'd want.
Alex moving down the hallway toward the suite. Spots the coming out. They acknowledge him. Frank does a double-tak
Alex. What are you doing here?
Katharine in there? Frank grabs Alex by the arm. Alex shoots him a look. Fran lets go.
Let me buy you a drink, Alex.
(hesitates; nods) Sure. Later, Frank, okay? I'll meet you in the bar. The last one out of the room is David Garth. Alex pushes him and into the suite.
Alex doesn't immediately see anyone. He walks to the bedr door, spots Delaney and Katharine inside.

Delaney rotates her neck, as though she is tense, tired. see Alex in b.g. Delaney presses her fingers against the muscles of her ne stares at Katharine, almost nostalgically. Through the mi on the dressing table:
